DEFEATED BY C. U.
Lose Home Meet By Score Of
38-28

Evening
Saturday night the Catholic University swimming team journeyed
from Washington to Baltimore to
defeat the Johns Hopkins team by a
score of 38 to 28. The meet was
held at the Knights of Columbus

Vol. XXXIV, No. 39

COSMOPOLITAN CLUB
TO MEET SATURDAY
T h e Cosmopolitan Club,
which was entertained by interpretative dancing at a tea
held Sunday, will hold its biweekly m eeting Saturday
night, March 22, in the social
room of Levering Hall. At the
conclusion of the business
session the members w ill
switch on the radio and hold
an informal dance.

ENGLISH PROFS AREN'T SO BAWDY,
SAYS C. K. D., THAT LITTLE DEVIL

The undergraduate English department is vindicated! C. K. D. has
confessed that the famous letter in
the "Y" News was just a hoax. A
hoax on the Y. M. C. A. as a matter
of fact. So one major problem is
solved, thus foreclosing further
campus debate on whether or not
C. K. D. was serious. But yet a
more vital question remains to be
solved; just who is this clever little
devil who masquerades under the
n o w famous pseudonym? The
answer has at last been found; he
is a member of that very group
Speaks At Assembly On "The
whom he has so wittingly defamed
New Way Of Things"
namely the English department.

Hand. He projected himself into
the mood of being a little devil. He
wrote a little devilish letter to the
"Y" News. He said he didn't like
to criticize but that the English
reading courses at Hopkins were
immensely dirty. He said he didn't
like to criticize but that the instructors were immensely dirty. He
said he didn't like to criticize but
that if this didn't stop, everybody,
else would be immensely dirty, too.

TENNIS SQUAD TO
ORGANIZE THURSDAY
An organization meeting of
the tennis team will be held
Thursday, March 20, at 12.20
in the Hullabaloo office. There
are several berths open on the
team as there are only three
of last year's veterans left on
this season's team. These are
Captain Helmholtz, Gump,and
Goldberg. Progress must be
made rapidly as there are only
three weeks remaining before
the first match of the season.

AT this time of the year we are all faced with the question of
whether it is worth while to go to college. The seniors look
back over their college years and wonder whether they would have been
better off had they never attended college. The underclassmen are
faced with the more practical problem of whether or not they should
return in the the fall.
The criterion of the value of your college education is not how many
facts you have assimilated nor is it a question of whether you have
learned anything that will be of practical benefit to you later on in life.
It is, of course, advantageous to have acquired information, particularly
information of a useful sort. But, under certain conditions, your college years have not been wasted if the only thing you have retained
from four years of class work is that the Battle of Hastings was fought
in 1066.
In considering the value of your college education as applied to your
later life, you must reflect not only upon the.question of whether or
not college has qualified you to make a success in life, but you must
also think as to whether or not college has taught you to enjoy a
success once made. We are all acquainted with the type of man who
has amassed a huge fortune in some form of mercantile endeavor and
then does not know what to do with it. Ask yourself whether your
college days have not opened new vistas to your eyes, have not taught
you to be content with books, have not freed you from the bond of
always needing something to do.
Further ask yourself if you have enjoyed your college career. Have
the four years at Homewood been an idyll which you are loathe to
leave? If you can truthfully answer "yes" to these questions; if college
has taught you how to enjoy yourself more fully in the years to come;
nay, even if you have merely enjoyed the four years that have passed,
college has been worth while.

THIS FARCE OF ELECTIONS
HO is to be the editor of the 1931 Hullabaloo? Who is to be
Wclassed
among the most popular men in my class? Who are we
the Student Council?

to elect as the next President of

One might well imagine that questions such as these would be
troubling the majority of undergraduates at present since elections
affecting the entire student body will take place shortly. But, as a matter
of fact, they are not even being considered by the vast majority of
students. A few politicians are busy seeking candidates, soon they will
nominate these men, then they will second them, then they will vote
on them, and finally they will declare them elected. And the majority
of students will blankly ask themselves what happened.
• Hopkins' elections are run by a group comprising less than onethird the total undergraduate enrollment. The remaining two-thirds
never do anything but grumble "Dirty Politics." Our professional
idealists (of whom there are a large number on the campus today, by
the way) cry out that politics are out of place in college and should be
done away with. The only way we can stop positions being traded
from one fraternity to another is for the entire campus to take enough
interest in student affairs to cast a vote at least.
We realize the tremendous energy required to walk over to the C.
E. Hall and drop a ballot in the box, but it has been done occasionally.
Some of those who have never tried it should prevail upon themselves
to do it at least once, if only to get in practice for the fall of 1932.
We advocate that no election be declared valid unless at least threequarters of the men qualified to vote do so. This applies to any election whatsoever from the President of the Student Council down to
Biggest Handshaker. In this way it may be possible to eliminate much
of the political dealing (both straight and crooked) that has infested
the campus during the past four years.

The undergraduate English department is vindicated! C. K. D. has
confessed that the famous letter in
the "Y" News was just a hoax. A
hoax on the Y. M. C. A. as a matter
of fact. So one major problem is
solved, thus foreclosing further
campus debate on whether or not
C. K. D. was serious. But yet a
more vital question remains to be
solved; just who is this clever little
devil who masquerades under the
n o w famous pseudonym? The
answer has at last been found; he
is a member of that very group
Speaks At Assembly On "The
whom he has so wittingly defamed
New Way Of Things"
namely the English department.

Hand. He projected himself into
the mood of being a little devil. He
wrote a little devilish letter to the
"Y" News. He said he didn't like
to criticize but that the English
reading courses at Hopkins were
immensely dirty. He said he didn't
like to criticize but that the instructors were immensely dirty. He
said he didn't like to criticize but
that if this didn't stop, everybody,
else would be immensely dirty, too.

AT this time of the year we are all faced with the question of
whether it is worth while to go to college. The seniors look
back over their college years and wonder whether they would have been
better off had they never attended college. The underclassmen are
faced with the more practical problem of whether or not they should
return in the the fall.
The criterion of the value of your college education is not how many
facts you have assimilated nor is it a question of whether you have
learned anything that will be of practical benefit to you later on in life.
It is, of course, advantageous to have acquired information, particularly
information of a useful sort. But, under certain conditions, your college years have not been wasted if the only thing you have retained
from four years of class work is that the Battle of Hastings was fought
in 1066.
In considering the value of your college education as applied to your
later life, you must reflect not only upon the.question of whether or
not college has qualified you to make a success in life, but you must
also think as to whether or not college has taught you to enjoy a
success once made. We are all acquainted with the type of man who
has amassed a huge fortune in some form of mercantile endeavor and
then does not know what to do with it. Ask yourself whether your
college days have not opened new vistas to your eyes, have not taught
you to be content with books, have not freed you from the bond of
always needing something to do.
Further ask yourself if you have enjoyed your college career. Have
the four years at Homewood been an idyll which you are loathe to
leave? If you can truthfully answer "yes" to these questions; if college
has taught you how to enjoy yourself more fully in the years to come;
nay, even if you have merely enjoyed the four years that have passed,
college has been worth while.

THIS FARCE OF ELECTIONS
HO is to be the editor of the 1931 Hullabaloo? Who is to be
Wclassed
among the most popular men in my class? Who are we
the Student Council?

to elect as the next President of

One might well imagine that questions such as these would be
troubling the majority of undergraduates at present since elections
affecting the entire student body will take place shortly. But, as a matter
of fact, they are not even being considered by the vast majority of
students. A few politicians are busy seeking candidates, soon they will
nominate these men, then they will second them, then they will vote
on them, and finally they will declare them elected. And the majority
of students will blankly ask themselves what happened.
• Hopkins' elections are run by a group comprising less than onethird the total undergraduate enrollment. The remaining two-thirds
never do anything but grumble "Dirty Politics." Our professional
idealists (of whom there are a large number on the campus today, by
the way) cry out that politics are out of place in college and should be
done away with. The only way we can stop positions being traded
from one fraternity to another is for the entire campus to take enough
interest in student affairs to cast a vote at least.
We realize the tremendous energy required to walk over to the C.
E. Hall and drop a ballot in the box, but it has been done occasionally.
Some of those who have never tried it should prevail upon themselves
to do it at least once, if only to get in practice for the fall of 1932.
We advocate that no election be declared valid unless at least threequarters of the men qualified to vote do so. This applies to any election whatsoever from the President of the Student Council down to
Biggest Handshaker. In this way it may be possible to eliminate much
of the political dealing (both straight and crooked) that has infested
the campus during the past four years.

WHY NOT take the time now to think
this over? To get anywhere in the world
of business—just as in driving an automobile — a man must choose a definite
road and keep on it.
Natural ability gives him power
to go ahead—college tunes him up
to go faster. But to get anywhere
he must have a "steering gear"

a guiding purpose, an ambition in life.
Every man has certain aptitudes and
interests that fit him peculiarly for one
kind of work rather than another. A little
careful self-analysis will help you to
get started in the right direction.
Industry always has room for the
man who knows what work
wants to do and can do.
